kubejs.ponder.ae2_multiblock.text_1: The Controller multiblock must fit in a 7x7x7 area.
kubejs.ponder.ae2_multiblock.text_2: A Controller block can only touch up to 3 other Controller blocks.
kubejs.ponder.ae2_multiblock.text_3: Placing a fourth Controller will disrupt the network.
kubejs.ponder.ae2_multiblock.text_4: Something like this is the most efficient design.
kubejs.ponder.ae2_multiblock.text_5: This setup has 48 easily-accessible sides, enough for 1536 channels!
kubejs.ponder.ae2_multiblock.text_6: It's highly recommended to use P2P Tunnels.
kubejs.ponder.ae2_multiblock.text_7: The middle blocks can each connect to 4 P2P Tunnels!
kubejs.ponder.ae2_multiblock.text_8: Including the center sides, there are 72 faces, enough for 2304 channels!
kubejs.ponder.ae2_single.text_1: The ME Controller is the brain of the network.
kubejs.ponder.ae2_single.text_10: Color your Cables to keep them separate.
kubejs.ponder.ae2_single.text_3: Done properly, a single Controller can support 192 channels
kubejs.ponder.ae2_single.text_5: You might think, "Why not just add another Controller wherever?"
kubejs.ponder.ae2_single.text_7: Having two separate Controllers will disrupt the network, shutting the whole thing down.
kubejs.ponder.ae2_single.text_8: However, placing Controllers together will form a multiblock!
kubejs.ponder.ae2_single.text_9: The more faces, the more channels!
kubejs.ponder.boiler_construction.text_1: The Thermoelectric Boiler uses Heat to turn Water into Steam.
Additional Heater layers are optional, but make it run faster and hold more Water.
Hollow layers (called Water Cavity layers) can optionally be included, to hold more Water.
Fill a layer with Pressure Dispersers to create a "Steam Catch layer." The entire layer must be filled.
Hollow layers (called Steam Cavity layers) can optionally be included, to hold more Steam
Cap it off, and you're almost done!
Replace two blocks on the casing on a Heater or Water Cavity layer with Valves.
One acts as a Water input...
Replace a block on the casing on a Steam Catch or Steam Cavity layer with another Valve.
This will act as the Steam output.
kubejs.ponder.boiler_construction.text_2: Its design is modular, here's how you make it.
And that's it! Your Boiler is now ready to run!
kubejs.ponder.boiler_construction.text_3: The Boiler can be anywhere from a 3x4x3 to 18x18x18.
kubejs.ponder.boiler_construction.text_6: Fill the next layer with Superheating Elements.
kubejs.ponder.boiler_construction.text_7: Surround this layer with Boiler Casing.
kubejs.ponder.boiler_construction.text_8: This layer is now a "Heater layer."
kubejs.ponder.boiler_construction.text_9: The non-corners can be Structural Glass instead
kubejs.ponder.endoflame_automation.text_: Endoflames are the most basic Mana-generating flower
This one stays until the Endoflame is ready for more, and then the cycle repeats.
This setup scales perfectly! It can power as many Endoflames as you can fit into the area
Endoflames use furnace fuel to fill their Mana Spreader
This setup will keep it running indefinitely
it'll push into the Open Crate, which drops it on the Pressure Plate.
This powers the Hopper, stopping it from sending more.
...depowering the Hopper so more fuel can be dropped!
kubejs.ponder.fission_construction.text_: The Fission Generator is a multiblock that generates a massive amount of heat.
Fill the walls with Reactor Glass (or more Reactor Casing).
Place a pillar of Fusion Fuel Assemblies anywhere inside
The more you put, the faster the Reactor burns fuel.
On top of the pillar, place a Control Rod Assembly.
This must be BELOW the Reactor's top, not part of it.
There can be multiple sets of Control Rods, but they cannot touch sides.
Anywhere on any of the sides, place 4 Fission Reactor Ports:
One for Fuel input
One for Coolant input
One for Heated Coolant output
It does this by coolant (like Water)...
And one for Radioactive Waste output
And now your Fission Reactor is complete!
Running it is VERY dangerous though, so make sure to read the quests explaining it!
...into something hotter (like Steam).
Fueled by Fissile Fuel..
...it creates dangerous Radioactive Waste as a byproduct.
This is how it's built.
It can be anywhere from 3x4x3 to 18x18x18
Build the frame out of Fission Reactor Casing
Cap the top and bottom as well.
kubejs.ponder.fusion_construction.text_1: Mekanism's Fusion Reactor can make an extreme amount of FE/t.
kubejs.ponder.fusion_construction.text_3: Use "Q" to see what each block is.
kubejs.ponder.fusion_construction.text_4: Any Frames that aren't on a corner can be replaced with Reactor Glass
kubejs.ponder.induction_construction.tex: The Induction Matrix is a modular multiblock that stores FE.
A max sized Matrix with the most Cells possible could store 6,552,000,000,000,000 FE!
Close it back up (air inside is fine)
FE is piped into the input Induction Port...
It must be a rectangular prism, but it can be anywhere from 3x3x4 to 18x18x18
The edges must be made out of Induction Casing...
...but the centers can have Induction Ports anywhere inside.
An Induction Provider must be placed anywhere inside.
Having more Induction Providers, or Providers of higher tiers, increases the rate FE can move in and out.
An Induction Cell must also be placed anywhere inside.
More Cells, or Cells of higher tiers, increase the capacity of the Matrix.
kubejs.ponder.mek_2x.text_1: Mekanism allows you to process ore through up to 5 steps, quintupling your output.
kubejs.ponder.mek_2x.text_2: This Ponder series will go through each step.
kubejs.ponder.mek_2x.text_3: The Enrichment is the simplest, doubling your ores.
kubejs.ponder.mek_2x.text_5: ...and it gives you twice as many Dust.
kubejs.ponder.mek_3x.text_1: 3x processing onwards is much more complex.
kubejs.ponder.mek_3x.text_5: Both of these Chemical Tanks were configured to output in the direction of the Separator.
kubejs.ponder.mek_3x.text_6: Only Oxygen is used in this step, but Hydrogen is needed later.
kubejs.ponder.mek_3x.text_7: The Purification Chamber uses Oxygen to convert Ores...
kubejs.ponder.mek_3x.text_9: The Crusher will convert each Clump...
kubejs.ponder.mek_4x.text_1: The Chemical Infuser makes Hydrogen Chloride by combining...
kubejs.ponder.mek_4x.text_3: ...as well as Chlorine, which needs a Thermal Evaporation Plant.
kubejs.ponder.mek_4x.text_4: Both of these Chemical Tanks were configured to output in the direction of the Separator.
kubejs.ponder.mek_4x.text_5: This Hydrogen Chloride is used in the Chemical Injection Chamber.
kubejs.ponder.mek_4x.text_8: Each Shard has to go through all the previous steps before it can be smelted.
kubejs.ponder.mek_5x.text_1: As the final step, 5x processing is by far the most complex.
kubejs.ponder.mek_5x.text_10: The Chemical Crystallizer will convert Clean Ore Slurry into Ore Crystals.
kubejs.ponder.mek_5x.text_11: For each Ore that goes through, you end up with 5 Crystals.
kubejs.ponder.mek_5x.text_12: Like the previous step, these Crystals have to go through the other three machines before they can be smelted.
kubejs.ponder.mek_5x.text_2: First, feed a Chemical Oxidizer some Sulfur, to make Sulfur Dioxide.
kubejs.ponder.mek_5x.text_3: Combine it with more Oxygen to make Sulfur Trioxide.
kubejs.ponder.mek_5x.text_4: This Chemical Tank was configured to output to the Infuser.
kubejs.ponder.mek_5x.text_5: Feed Water to a Rotary Condenstrator to make Water Vapor
kubejs.ponder.mek_5x.text_6: Combine the Sulfur Trioxide and Water Vapor to make Sulfuric Acid.
kubejs.ponder.mek_5x.text_7: This Chemical Tank was configured to output to the Infuser.
kubejs.ponder.mek_5x.text_8: Combine Ores with Sulfuric Acid to get Dirty Ore Slurry
kubejs.ponder.mek_5x.text_9: Wash the Dirty Slurry with Water to make Clean Ore Slurry
kubejs.ponder.mgu_farm.text_1: Mob Grinding Utils makes mob farms much easier to make!
kubejs.ponder.mgu_farm.text_10: There's no real size limit, the only bottleneck is how fast you can kill what spawns
kubejs.ponder.mgu_farm.text_11: With Upgrades, your Mob Masher can have Sharpness 10
kubejs.ponder.mgu_farm.text_4: Vector Plates move mobs standing on them
kubejs.ponder.mgu_farm.text_5: The Mob Masher damages anything touching it
kubejs.ponder.mgu_farm.text_6: The Absorption Hopper picks up items and xp
kubejs.ponder.mgu_farm.text_7: You can set it to push into an adjacent inventory
kubejs.ponder.mgu_farm.text_8: The Enderman Inhibitor prevents Endermen from teleporting away
kubejs.ponder.mgu_farm.text_9: Dreadful Dirt turns off when lit, so you can use Redstone Lamps to toggle it
kubejs.ponder.spatial_storage_big.text_1: Spatial IO costs a large amount of energy, especially for bigger structures.
You can keep adding more lines for even higher efficiency.
With these, it's at 66.66% effiency, costing 7.92 million FE.
Additional Pylons can also be vertical!
With these, the SCS is at 100% efficiency, and only costs 1.62 million FE!
Each line of Pylons takes up a channel.
While this isn't a problem for smaller or less efficient SCSs, larger ones will need a Controller.
kubejs.ponder.spatial_storage_big.text_2: This SCS is 8x7x8, and costs a massive 48,600,000 FE!
kubejs.ponder.spatial_storage_big.text_3: Each SCS has an "Efficiency" percentage, visible in the IO Port.
kubejs.ponder.spatial_storage_big.text_4: This SCS has an efficiency of 28.57%, which is why it costs so much.
kubejs.ponder.spatial_storage_big.text_5: If we can raise the efficiency, we can lower the FE cost!
kubejs.ponder.spatial_storage_big.text_6: Add another line of Pylons, parallel to one of the existing ones.
kubejs.ponder.spatial_storage_big.text_7: The efficiency is now 38.09%, and the cost is now 30.88 million FE.
kubejs.ponder.spatial_storage_big.text_8: You don't have to put a full line, but it's more efficient to.
kubejs.ponder.spatial_storage_big.text_9: Adding only two brings the efficiency to only 30.95%, and the cost to 43.39 million FE.
kubejs.ponder.spatial_storage_simple.tex: AE2's Spatial Storage allows you to take an area in the world and store it digitally.
Traditionally, the Pylons are placed like this...
...but for visibility's sake, let's keep it here.
So long as they're surrounding the same area, it doesn't matter.
Attach the Pylons to the same network...
...and connect a Spatial IO Port as well.
This entire structure is called the Spatial Containment Structure.
You can only have one per network...
...though really, these are often single-use only.
Insert a Spatial Storage Cell...
...give it a Redstone signal...
The smallest Spatial Storage Cell can hold a 2x2x2 volume, and the largest can hold up to a 128x128x128.
...and the structure is stored into the Disk!
Now you can take this filled Disk and bring it home.
Recreate the Spatial Containment Structure.
Insert the Spatial Storage Cell...
...give it a Redstone signal...
...and the structure will exit the Cell!
A note: Entities (including Players) can also get caught!
If you accidentally get caught in the Spatial Storage dimension, you will be STUCK THERE!
The only way to get back out is teleportation, commands, death, or getting someone/something in the overworld to un-store you.
We'll go over the smallest one first.
Say we find some Flawless Budding Certus Quartz.
We want to bring it home, but we can't safely mine it.
So, instead we'll use Spatial Storage!
Place Spatial Pylons around the area you want to move.
They must by one block longer than the area being moved!
Here, since we're moving a 2x2x2 volume, each Pylon must be 3 long.
kubejs.ponder.sps_construction.text_1: The SPS turns energy and Polonium into Antimatter.
kubejs.ponder.sps_construction.text_12: Any Port can be anywhere inside any circle.
kubejs.ponder.sps_construction.text_13: The Supercharged Coil has to be on the Port that accepts power.
kubejs.ponder.sps_construction.text_14: The two can be placed on the sides as well
kubejs.ponder.sps_construction.text_15: The more powered Coils, the faster Antimatter is created!
kubejs.ponder.sps_construction.text_3: Basically, six 7-wide circles of SPS Casing with stuff inside
kubejs.ponder.sps_construction.text_4: The inside of the circle can be made of any of these:
kubejs.ponder.sps_construction.text_8: Three SPS Ports must be placed inside any of the circles.
kubejs.ponder.tank_construction.text_1: The Dynamic Tank is a modular multiblock that stores a fluid.
kubejs.ponder.tank_construction.text_3: Make a cuboid frame out of Dynamic Tank blocks...
kubejs.ponder.tank_construction.text_4: ...and fill the sides with either more Tank blocks or Structural Glass.
kubejs.ponder.tank_construction.text_5: For every block that makes up the Tank (including edges), the Tank can hold 16 buckets of fluid.
kubejs.ponder.tank_construction.text_6: The smallest Tank (3x3x3) holds 432 buckets, and the largest Tank (18x18x18) holds 93,312.
kubejs.ponder.tank_construction.text_7: Replace two blocks with Dynamic Valves.
kubejs.ponder.tank_construction.text_8: That really is it! Your tank is now ready!
kubejs.ponder.turbine_construction.text_: The Industrial Turbine is a multiblock that uses Steam to generate massive amounts of FE.
The walls can be made of Structural Glass, but the corners must be Turbine Casing.
Place a Rotational Complex on the Rotors...
...and completely fill the rest of that layer with Pressure Dispersers.
The more room under this layer, the more Steam the Turbine can hold.
Place an Electromagnetic Coil on the Rotational Complex.
The amount of Coils (and of Rotor Blades) is what decides how much FE is generated.
You can have multiple layers of Coil.
The amount of Vents (and of Presssure Dispersers) is what decides the flow rate.
Higher flow rate means more Steam is used, and more FE is produced.
You can also place some Saturating Condensers down, which let you pull Water out of the vents.
This is how it's built.
Place a Valve for Steam input...
...and another for FE output!
First, place a base of Casing.
It can be anywhere from 5x5 to 17x17.
Place some Rotors in the middle.
The wider your Turbine, the taller it can be.
Attach Turbine Blades
If the Blades reach out far enough they would go through the walls...
...then you have to make the Turbine either shorter or wider.
